properties.Title: Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of squalls with wind gusts up to 35 knots, frequent lightning and poor to very poor visibility in thunderstorms heavy at times. ### Proceed with caution as visibility may suddenly be reduced to near zero. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. For more information monitor Canadian Coast Guard radio or Weatheradio stations.
Expires: 2019-08-19T23:37:48-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-08-19T07:37:48-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2681676124.2019

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: There is a risk of severe thunderstorms late this evening. An initial area of thunderstorms has moved through much of Southwestern Ontario. There is a potential for some of the thunderstorms to become severe. ### Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm. For more information: http://www.emergencymanagementontario.ca/english/beprepared/beprepared.html.
Expires: 2019-08-19T11:44:25-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-08-19T03:00:25-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0772990626.2019

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, heavy at times is expected. Heavy rain and strong winds today and tonight over Arviat ending Tuesday. A slow moving low pressure system over Hudson Bay will continue to bring heavy rain and strong northeast winds to southern Kivalliq. At 5:00 am this morning 18 mm of rain had already fallen overnight. Total rainfall amounts will range between 30-50 mm by Tuesday morning before the rainfall starts to taper off. Northeasterly winds, gusting at times to 80 km/h, will moderate slightly this afternoon and continue to moderate tonight into Tuesday. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2019-08-20T02:17:51-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-08-19T10:18:51-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0642459761.2019
Area: Arviat
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. Heavy rainfall continues to affect portions of Northern Ontario overnight. Total rainfall amounts may exceed 50 mm in spots. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-08-19T14:19:20-00:00

Area: Little Abitibi - Kesagami Lake
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long period of snowfall with total amounts of 20 to 30 cm continues. Early-season heavy snow for part of the Alaska Highway. The combination of an unseasonably cold arctic airmass and Pacific moisture associated with a low on the North Coast will result in continued heavy snow for higher elevations between Fort Nelson and Watson Lake. Total snowfall accumulations of 15 to 35 cm are expected through tonight. The town of Fort Nelson should receive rain while areas south of Fort Nelson may see up to 10 cm. The heavy snow is forecast to ease Monday morning. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Heavy snowfall accumulation may cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-08-19T14:45:34-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-08-18T22:46:34-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4126499299.2019
Area: Fort Nelson
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. Heavy rainfall continues to affect portions of Northern Ontario early this evening and is spreading towards the northeast. Some areas have received in excess of 40 mm as of early evening. Total rainfall amounts may exceed 50 mm in spots. Areas likely to be most affected include Fraserdale, Someky Falls, Ranoke, Onakawana, Galeton, and Fort Albany,. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-08-19T11:19:18-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-08-19T03:09:18-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4281754293.2019
Area: Fraserdale - Pledger Lake, Kapuskasing - Hearst - Smooth Rock Falls
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. Heavy rainfall continues to affect portions of Northern Ontario early this evening and is spreading towards the northeast. Some areas have received in excess of 40 mm as of early evening. Total rainfall amounts may exceed 50 mm in spots. Areas likely to be most affected include Hearst, Fort Albany, Hornepayne, Nagagamisis Provincial Park, Mammamattawa and Fushimi Lake Provincial Park. The heaviest rain should remain west of the town of Kapuskasing. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

Description: A long period of snowfall with total amounts of 20 to 30 cm continues. Early-season heavy snow for part of the Alaska Highway. The combination of an unseasonably cold arctic airmass and Pacific moisture associated with a low on the North Coast will result in continued heavy snow for higher elevations between Fort Nelson and Watson Lake. Total snowfall accumulations of 15 to 35 cm are expected through tonight. The town of Fort Nelson should receive rain while areas south of Fort Nelson may see up to 10 cm. properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms that may be capable of producing strong wind gusts and heavy rain. Boaters may be surprised by strong gusts over bodies of water. ### Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-08-19T20:39:37-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-08-19T08:40:37-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2241023288.2019
